questions.text: A female singer with hoarseness of voice, unable to sing higher frequency notes. Bowed and depressed unilateral vocal cord is seen. Which muscle is involved? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cricothyroid

  

The cricothyroid muscle is responsible for tensing the vocal cords, which allows for the production of higher frequency sounds. When the vocal cords are tightly stretched, they vibrate at a higher frequency, which is necessary for producing high-pitched notes.

 

In this scenario, the female singer is unable to sing higher frequency notes, indicating that her vocal cords are not adequately tense. This suggests paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle, which normally maintains the tension of the vocal cords. If the cricothyroid muscle is paralyzed, typically due to damage to the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, the vocal cords become bowed, loose, and floppy, impairing the ability to produce high-frequency sounds.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior cricoarytenoid: This muscle is the only abductor of the vocal cords, which means it separates the vocal cords during breathing. It does not contribute to tensing the vocal cords for high-frequency sound production.

 

Option B. Thyroarytenoid: This muscle acts as both an adductor and a relaxer of the vocal cords, contributing to lowering the pitch of the voice rather than raising it. It does not tense the vocal cords and, therefore, does not aid in the production of higher frequency notes.

 

Option D. Interarytenoid: This muscle functions as an adductor, helping to bring the vocal cords together. It does not have a role in tensing the vocal cords for higher frequencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cricothyroid muscle is essential for producing high-frequency notes by tensing the vocal cords. Paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle leads to the inability to produce these higher notes due to a lack of tension in the vocal cords.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Bandage and padding of the eye

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient who had undergone an uneventful cataract surgery with intraocular lens implantation, presents with complaints of pain and visual disturbance in the operated eye, 36 hours post operatively. His eye is as shown below. What is the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Intravitreal antibiotics

 

The given image shows an inflamed eye with the presence hypopyon, which along with the history of a recent cataract surgery is suggestive of endophthalmitis.

 

Endophthalmitis is an inflammation of the inner structures of the eyeball associated with exudate pouring in the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber, and posterior chamber.

 

Modes of infection:

 

  1. Exogenous: following perforating injuries, perforation of infected corneal ulcers, or postoperative infections.
  2. Endogenous or metastatic endophthalmitis: occurs rarely through the bloodstream from some infected focus.
  3. Secondary infections from surrounding structures: rare.
  • Bacterial endophthalmitis: most frequent pathogens are gram-positive cocci, such as staphylococcus epidermidis and staphylococcus aureus.
  • Fungal endophthalmitis: comparatively rare, caused by aspergillus, fusarium, candida, etc.
  • Cardinal features: Pain, lid swelling, and decreased vision. Inflammation of the eye, corneal edema, and hypopyon may also occur.
  • Treatment:
    • Intraocular fluid from anterior chamber or vitreous biopsy is sent for gram staining, KOH mount and culture.
    • Intravitreal injection of antibiotics is the primary therapy. Patient needs to be monitored daily to assess for resolution of clinical symptoms and repeat intravitreal antibiotic injections may be given as required.
    • Topical broadspectrum antibiotics, cycloplegics are also given simultaneously.
    • Oral steroids may be given.
    • Systemic antibiotics have no role in the management of endophthalmitis..

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous steroids: Not the primary treatment for endophthalmitis. Steroids may be used to reduce inflammation but not as the main intervention.

 

Option B. Intravenous antibiotics: Systemic antibiotics have limited effectiveness due to poor penetration into the eye.

 

Option C. Bandage and padding of the eye: Provides no therapeutic benefit for endophthalmitis and delays appropriate treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intravitreal antibiotics are the primary treatment for endophthalmitis, a severe postoperative complication characterized by inflammation and hypopyon. Early and aggressive treatment is crucial to prevent vision loss.

questions.text: In extroversion, what is the yoke muscle of the right lateral rectus muscle? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Left medial rectus

 

The yoke muscle of the right LR is the left MR.

 

Yoke muscles are the primary muscles in each eye that accomplish a given version (eg, for right gaze, the right lateral rectus and left medial rectus muscles).

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left superior oblique: This muscle is involved in intorsion, depression, and abduction of the left eye, not in coordinating rightward gaze with the right lateral rectus.

 

Option C. Left inferior rectus: This muscle is responsible for depression and adduction of the left eye, not relevant to the rightward gaze.

 

Option D. Left superior rectus: This muscle is involved in elevation and intorsion of the left eye, not in the horizontal movement to the right.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In extroversion (rightward gaze), the yoke muscle for the right lateral rectus (which abducts the right eye) is the left medial rectus (which adducts the left eye), enabling coordinated horizontal movement.

choices.text: Rinne’s test positive , Weber’s test lateralized to left ear
Rinne’s test positive , Weber’s test lateralized to right ear
Rinne’s test negative , Weber’s test lateralized to left ear
Rinne’s test negative , Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with bilateral hearing loss with worsened right ear hearing loss. On examination, the doctor diagnose Otosclerosis and recommends stapedectomy as a final resort to the problem. What would be the findings of tuning fork tests based on which the doctor has recommended stapedectomy? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rinne’s test negative, Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

 

  • Rinne’s test negative: Typical of otosclerosis, indicating conductive hearing loss where BC > AC.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to right ear: Indicates that the sound is heard better in the ear with more conductive loss, which matches otosclerosis more severely affecting the right ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rinne’s test positive, Weber’s test lateralized to left ear:

 

  • Rinne’s test positive: Indicates that air conduction (AC) is better than bone conduction (BC), which is a normal finding and typically not expected in conductive hearing loss like otosclerosis.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to left ear: In a case of unilateral or asymmetric hearing loss, Weber's test lateralizes to the better hearing ear in sensorineural hearing loss and to the poorer ear in conductive hearing loss. This pattern does not fit otosclerosis affecting the right ear more severely.

 

Option B. Rinne’s test positive, Weber’s test lateralized to right ear:

 

  • Rinne’s test positive: Again, indicates normal AC > BC, not typical for otosclerosis.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to right ear: Would suggest either a sensorineural hearing loss on the left ear or less likely conductive loss on the right, which doesn’t match typical otosclerosis findings.

 

Option C. Rinne’s test negative, Weber’s test lateralized to left ear:

 

  • Rinne’s test negative: Indicates that BC > AC, suggesting conductive hearing loss, typical of otosclerosis.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to left ear: Would imply the left ear is either better or has conductive loss, not aligning with greater hearing loss in the right ear due to otosclerosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The combination of a negative Rinne test and Weber test lateralizing to the ear with more hearing loss is indicative of conductive hearing loss in that ear. In otosclerosis, the ossification of the stapes leads to mechanical dysfunction, preventing effective sound transmission, hence a stapedectomy might be recommended to mechanically bypass the ossified stapes and improve hearing.

choices.text: Cessation of smoking and do biopsy

questions.text: A patient present with oral cavity findings as seen in the image below. He is a smoker. What would you choose as your next step in the management of this patient? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cessation of smoking and do biopsy

 

  • The next step of management of this patient will be cessation of smoking and do a biopsy.
  • The patient is a chronic smoker and the following image shows leukoplakia. Leukoplakia is a premalignant condition of the oral cavity.

 

The management include: 

 

  1. Elimination of associated aetiological factors and biopsy of the lesion. Many of the lesions will disappear spontaneously if the causative agent is removed.
  2. In lesions with higher potential for malignant change, a biopsy is taken to rule out malignancy.
  3. In suspicious small lesions, surgical excision or ablation with laser or cryotherapy can be done.

 

A photographic record of the lesion is useful for long term follow up.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Give corticosteroids: There is no role for corticosteroids in the treatment of leukoplakia as they do not address the potential for malignant transformation or the underlying causes of the lesion.

 

Option C. Lifestyle Modifications: While beneficial overall, lifestyle changes alone are insufficient for managing a lesion with potential malignancy. Specific interventions like quitting smoking are required.

 

Option D. Injection vitamin B12: There is no indication that vitamin B12 injections would be effective in treating leukoplakia unless there is a specific deficiency that also needs addressing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For leukoplakia, particularly in smokers, the primary management strategy includes cessation of smoking and histological examination through biopsy. This is crucial not only to assess the current state of the lesion but also to guide further therapeutic decisions which may include surgical excision, laser ablation, or cryotherapy depending on the biopsy results. Regular monitoring and photographic documentation of the lesion are also important for long-term follow-up.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 253

questions.text: The Koeppe nodules is seen in: (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iris

 

Iris nodules are seen in both, granulomatous and non-granulomatous anterior uveitis.

 

They are of 2 types - based on location:

 

1. Koeppes’s nodules: present at pupillary margin on the iris, and may be the site of posterior synechiae formation. seen in both, granulomatous and non-granulomatous anterior uveitis

 

2. Busacca’s nodules: present near the collarette in the body of iris. They are larger and less common, seen in granulomatous uveitis.

 

Other iris signs seen in anterior uveitis:

 

  • Edematous iris with muddy color
  • Posterior synechiae: adhesions between anterior surface of lens and posterior surface of iris
  • Adhesions around 360° of pupillary margin is called ring or annular synechiae (also called seclusio pupillae).

It results in ‘iris bombe’ formation (increased IOP due to collection of aqueous behind iris).

Iris bombe (Total posterior synechiae) also results in funnel shaped anterior chamber (deepest at centre and shallow in the periphery).

 

Findings of granulomatous uveitis:

 

  • Deposition of large Mutton fat Keratic precipitates on the back of the cornea: Large, fluffy precipitates made of macrophages and epithelioid cells having waxy or greasy appearance.
  • Absent aqueous flare.
  • Busacca nodules

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sclera: Koeppe nodules are not found in the sclera. The sclera may exhibit other signs of inflammation such as scleritis, but it does not develop Koeppe nodules.

 

Option C. Conjunctiva: The conjunctiva can show signs of inflammation such as conjunctivitis, but it does not develop Koeppe nodules.

 

Option D. Cornea: The cornea can exhibit deposits known as keratic precipitates in cases of uveitis, particularly granulomatous uveitis, but it does not develop Koeppe nodules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Koeppe nodules are located at the pupillary margin of the iris and are associated with both granulomatous and non-granulomatous anterior uveitis.

questions.text: Which nerve is responsible for referred otalgia from dental caries in lower molars? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trigeminal nerve

 

Explanation:

 

Dental pain from lower molars is referred to the ear via the mandibular branch (V3) of the trigeminal nerve because:

  • The trigeminal nerve provides sensory innervation to all teeth and surrounding structures
  • Mandibular branch (V3) specifically supplies: 
    • Lower teeth and gums
    • Floor of mouth
    • Anterior 2/3 of tongue
    • Mandible and temporomandibular joint
  • Through its auriculotemporal branch, it also supplies: 
    • External auditory canal
    • Anterior part of tympanic membrane
    • Temporal region

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glossopharyngeal nerve: Responsible for referred pain from tonsils, posterior 1/3 of tongue, and pharynx

 

Option B. Facial nerve: Primarily motor to facial muscles; not involved in pain transmission

 

Option D. Vagus nerve: Mediates referred pain from larynx, vallecula, and pyriform fossa

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Understanding the neural pathways of referred otalgia is crucial for accurate diagnosis. The trigeminal nerve's role in dental pain referral to the ear demonstrates the complex sensory connections between the oral cavity and ear.

questions.text: A patient came to the ophthalmology OPD with corneal abrasion, corneal ulcer, corneal perforation and foreign body. Which of the following will not cause hypotonic maculopathy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Suprachoroidal hemorrhage

 

  • Suprachoroidal hemorrhage does not cause hypotonic maculopathy in this patient.
  • Signs of Suprachoroidal hemorrhage include the following:
  •  
    • Anterior chamber shallowing
    • Loss of the red reflex
    • Increased IOP, with firming of the eye
    • Wrinkling and bulging of the posterior capsule
    • Extrusion of intraocular contents: spontaneous nuclear expression, iris prolapse, vitreous prolapse
  • Maculopathy is a common consequence of hypotony, defined as IOP less than 5 mmHg.
  • Excessive drainage following glaucoma filtration surgery is the most common cause of hypotonic maculopathy.
  • Other causes include trauma (cyclodialysis cleft, penetrating injury), chronic uveitis, retinal detachment.
  • Systemic causes of hypotony, usually bilateral, include dehydration, uncontrolled diabetes with hyperglycaemia, uraemia, and treatment with hyperosmotic agents or carbonic anhydrase inhibitors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cyclodialysis of uvea: This refers to the disinsertion of the ciliary body from the scleral spur, a trauma-related occurrence that can lead to a direct decrease in IOP, potentially causing hypotonic maculopathy.

 

Option C. Corneal perforation: Severe enough corneal damage, such as perforation, can lead to loss of aqueous humor and a subsequent decrease in IOP, posing a risk for hypotonic maculopathy.

 

Option D. Filtration site leak: This condition is specifically associated with glaucoma surgery where a leak at the filtration site can lead to a significant reduction in IOP, making it a direct cause of hypotonic maculopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Suprachoroidal hemorrhage does not lead to hypotonic maculopathy because it typically causes an increase in intraocular pressure, not a decrease. Understanding the distinction between conditions that increase versus those that decrease IOP is critical in the management of eye conditions and their potential complications.

questions.text: A patient recently underwent LASIK surgery for her myopia. She is now complaining of headaches and eye pain. Identify the test being performed on her: (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tonometry

 

  • The image depicts the use of an Applanation tonometry. It is based on the applanation principle described by Imbert and Fick. With regards to applanation tonometry, the law states that pressure (P) can be approximated by the force (F) necessary to flatten the cornea in a fixed area, divided by the surface (S) of the flattened area. The Imbert-Fick law is defined as P=F/S.
  • The dynamic contour tonometer (Pascal) for tonometry looks as

 

 

  • Intraocular pressure (IOP) readings obtained with this tonometer are not influenced by central corneal thickness.
  • The Pascal tonometer is the preferred tonometer for measuring IOP in post-LASIK corneas.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Pachymetry: This test measures the thickness of the cornea. It is important for assessing the cornea pre-LASIK but is not depicted in the image nor directly associated with measuring IOP.

 

 

Option C. Autorefractometry: This procedure determines the refractive error and prescription for glasses or contact lenses. It does not involve contact with the eye as depicted and is unrelated to IOP measurement.

 

 

Option D. A scan: This ultrasound test measures the length of the eye and is primarily used in cataract surgery planning. It does not involve the measurement of IOP.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tonometry, especially applanation tonometry, is crucial for monitoring intraocular pressure post-LASIK surgery to ensure no adverse effects on eye pressure, which could lead to symptoms like headaches and eye pain as described. This test is essential for the ongoing evaluation of patients' eye health following refractive surgery.

questions.text: CT scan of a patient with laryngeal carcinoma is shown below. Single ipsilateral < 3cm node is seen. What is the staging? (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. T4N1M0

The given CT image is consistent with a staging of T4N1M0. It depicts a large glottic-subglottic mass with massive cricoid and thyroid invasion and extra laryngeal spread indicating a T4 stage.

Above shown is CT scan of a 72-year-old patient with T4a laryngeal cancer (red arrows) showing a large extralaryngeal extension through the left side of the thyroid cartilage. Indication of primary total laryngectomy.

Other Options:

Option A. T1N0M0: Would indicate a tumor confined to one subsite with no lymph node involvement or distant metastasis, which does not correlate with the extensive involvement shown in the image.

Option C. T2N1M0: Suggests tumor involvement of adjacent subsites or impaired vocal cord mobility, which is less extensive than that shown.

Option D. T3N0M0: Indicates more advanced local disease than T2 but without the extensive extra-laryngeal spread or significant lymph node involvement shown in the image.

Educational Objective:

TNM STAGING FOR CA LARYNX:

T1 – Only 1 subsite (supraglottis/glottis/subglottis)

T2 – Involves adjacent subsites or sites, impaired vocal cord mobility.

T3 – Involving Pre-epiglottic space & post-cricoid area, fixed vocal cords.

T4a – Local invasion through thyroid cartilage or tissues beyond larynx

T4b – Invasion to distant places (prevertebral space, mediastinum, carotid, etc)

N0 – No cervical lymph nodes

N1 – Single ipsilateral < 3cm

N2 – Single ipsilateral 3-6cm / multiple ipsilateral, contralateral or bilateral < 6cm

N3 – Single or multiple nodes > 6cm

M0 – No metastasis

M1 – Metastasis present

Ref: Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 348

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with white pupillary reflex in the right eye. CT scan shows a cauliflower like growth arising from the retina with calcifications within. What is the likely diagnosis?(FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Retinoblastoma

 

Retinoblastoma:

 

  • Most common eye tumor in children.
  • Rb1 gene located on 13q14, requires both alleles mutation (Knudson’s hypothesis).
  • Rb1 gene is a tumor suppressor gene.
  • Most common presentation is leukocoria.
  • 2nd most common symptom is squint.
  • Clinical Features:

i) Quiescent stage:

  • Characterized by Leukocoria which is also known as Amaurotic cat’s eye appearance, convergent squint, defective vision and nystagmus (seen in bilateral cases).
  • Ophthalmoscopically, endophytic retinoblastoma gives “cottage cheese appearance” whereas exophytic tumor present as exudative retinal detachment.

 

ii) Glaucomatous stage:

  • Presents as severe pain, redness and watering. It may also result in hyphaema or pseudohypopyon (contains tumor cells).

 

iii) Extraocular extension:

  • Globe burst through sclera near limbus and presents as marked proptosis.

 

iv) Distant metastasis:

  • Metastasis of retinoblastoma spread to 
    • Optic nerve via direct extension
    • Pre-auricular lymph nodes via lymphatics
    • Cranial bones via blood
  • Microscopy – Flexner Wintersteiner rosettes
  • Treatment:
    • Enucleation
    • Chemotherapy→ intra-arterial chemo – melphalan in ophthalmic artery is very successful.
    • VEC regime is very successful:

 

V – Vincristine

E – Etoposide

C – Carboplatin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinal detachment: Typically presents with visual disturbances such as floaters, flashes of light, and a shadow or curtain over part of the visual field. It does not typically present with a cauliflower-like growth or calcifications on a CT scan.

 

Option B. Keratitis: Involves inflammation of the cornea, presenting with pain, redness, and blurred vision, not a white pupillary reflex or retinal growth.

 

Option D. Pterygium: A benign growth on the conjunctiva that can extend onto the cornea. It does not cause leukocoria or a cauliflower-like growth on a CT scan.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinoblastoma is the most common eye tumor in children and can be identified by leukocoria and a characteristic cauliflower-like growth with calcifications on imaging.

 

Other common causes of leukocoria are-

 

  • Coats disease
  • Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP)
  • Persistent fetal vasculature (PFV)
  • Ocular toxocariasis and toxoplasmosis
  • Astrocytic hamartoma
  • Familial exudative vitreoretinopathy (FEVR)
  • Vitreous haemorrhage

questions.text: During a health visit at a local school, you come across a child exhibiting delayed speech development. An otoscopic examination of the ear reveals the appearance shown below. Additionally, audiometric tests indicate a hearing loss of 20 dB. What would be your diagnosis for the child? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Serous otitis media

 

The provided clinical scenario, combined with the otoscopy image displaying air-fluid levels, indicates a diagnosis of serous otitis media.

 

CLINICAL FEATURES IN SEROUS OTITIS MEDIA

 

  • Hearing Loss is the presenting symptom. It is insidious in onset and rarely the only symptom.
  • Delayed development of speech
  • Mild earache

 

OTOSCOPIC FINDINGS IN SEROUS OTITIS MEDIA

 

  • Tympanic membrane is dull and opaque with loss of light reflex.
  • It may appear yellow, grey or bluish in color.
  • Thin leash of blood vessels may be seen along the handle of malleus or at the periphery of tympanic membrane and differs from marked congestion of acute suppurative otitis media.
  • Tympanic membrane may show varying degree of retraction. Sometimes, it may appear full or slightly bulging in its posterior part due to effusion.
  • Fluid level and air bubbles may be seen when fluid is thin and tympanic membrane transparent
  • Mobility of the tympanic membrane is restricted

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute suppurative otitis media is an acute inflammation of middle ear by pyogenic organisms. Tympanic membrane is retracted with handle of malleus assuming a more horizontal position, prominence of lateral process of malleus and loss of light reflex. A cart-wheel appearance can be appreciated in later stages.

 

 

Option C. Chronic suppurative otitis media means long-standing infection of middle ear with discharge and permanent perforation.

 

Option D. Glomus tumor patients presents with hearing loss & tinnitus (pulsatile, swishing, synchronous with pulse).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serous otitis media is a common cause of conductive hearing loss in children and can significantly impact speech development if untreated. It typically resolves spontaneously, but persistent cases require intervention to prevent long-term speech and language complications.

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 69

questions.text: A farmer presented to the ophthalmological emergency with blurred vision, redness, tearing, photophobia, pain and foreign body sensation following a stick injury of the eye. Examination reveals a corneal ulcer with fuzzy margins and redness. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fungal keratitis

 

 

Fungal Keratitis

 

  • Fusarium and Aspergillus fumigatus are the most common causes around the world, while candida is the most common cause in temperate regions.

 

Predisposing Factors

 

  • Injury by vegetative materials or animal tail—most common
  • Long-term use of topical steroids or antibiotics
  • Prior corneal transplantation
  • Contact lens wear
  • Diabetes mellitus.

 

Clinical Features

 

  • Symptoms are mild as compared to the signs.
  • Mild pain, watering and photophobia are seen, but ciliary and conjunctival congestion are marked.
  • Characteristic features of corneal ulcer are—dry looking, grayish white with elevated rolled out margins and feathery finger-like extensions into surrounding stroma under intact epithelium, with satellite nodules.
  • A sterile immune ring of Wesseley is seen where fungal antigen and host antibody meet.
  • Hypopyon is seen, which is often large and unsterile (pseudohypopyon) as fungi can penetrate into anterior chamber without perforation.

 

Diagnosis

 

  • Examination of wet KOH mount, calcofluor white for fungal hyphae and culture on Sabouraud’s medium.

 

Treatment

 

  • Natamycin and amphotericin B are the 1st line drugs.
  • Imidazole and flucytosine are used in candida infection.
  • Cycloplegics as atropine or scopolamine are used to reduce ciliary spasm, uveal inflammation and prevent posterior synechiae formation.
  • Anti-inflammatory and analgesics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpes simplex keratitis: Typically presents with dendritic ulcers and decreased corneal sensations, not with fuzzy margins and the specific history of trauma with vegetative material.

 

Option B. Acanthamoeba keratitis: Often associated with contact lens use and presents with severe pain, perineural infiltrates, and ring infiltrates, rather than fuzzy margins.

 

Option C. Bacterial keratitis: Usually presents with a round, well-demarcated ulcer, and is less commonly associated with trauma by vegetative material. It does not present with the dry, feathery, grayish white ulcers characteristic of fungal keratitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fungal keratitis is commonly associated with trauma by vegetative material and presents with characteristic dry, grayish white corneal ulcers with feathery margins and satellite nodules.

questions.text: For what condition is the Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA) utilized? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Congenital external auditory atresia

 

Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA) is utilized in congenital external auditory canal atresia.

 

Bone-Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA)

 

It has 3 parts. The titanium screw is fitted into skull bone behind mastoid and left for 6 months for osseous integration to occur. The processor is fitted into this screw with help of abutment. Suits better for people with canal problems or congenital aural atresia.

 

Indications for BAHA

 

  1. When air-conduction (AC) hearing aid cannot be used:
    1. Canal atresia, congenital or acquired, not amenable to treatment.
    2. Chronic ear discharge, not amenable to treatment.
    3. Excessive feedback and discomfort from air-conduction hearing aid.
  2. Conductive or mixed hearing loss, e.g., otosclerosis and tympanosclerosis where surgery is contraindicated.
  3. Single-sided hearing loss.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sensorineural hearing loss: BAHA can be used for single-sided sensorineural hearing loss but is not typically the first choice for bilateral sensorineural hearing loss.

 

Option B. Acoustic neuroma: While BAHA may help restore hearing on the side affected by an acoustic neuroma, this is not the primary indication.

 

Option D. Otitis media: Chronic otitis media can be an indication for BAHA if traditional hearing aids cannot be used due to recurrent infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BAHA is a valuable hearing solution for patients with congenital external auditory atresia or other conditions where traditional hearing aids are impractical. It provides an alternative auditory pathway by directly stimulating the cochlea via bone conduction, effectively bypassing problems in the outer or middle ear.

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 136, 137

questions.text:
Which of the following are the objective tests for the hearing? (INICET May 2021)

 

  1. BERA (Brainstem evoked response audiometry)
  2. OAE (Otoacoustic emission)
  3. PTA (Pure tone audiometry)
  4. Tympanometry
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4

 

Objective tests for hearing do not require the active cooperation or response from the patient and are thus particularly useful in non-cooperative subjects such as young children or those who might simulate hearing loss.

 

1. BERA - Also called BAER or BAEP (brainstem auditory evoked response or potential) is an objective test to elicit brainstem responses to auditory stimulation by clicks or tone bursts. It is a noninvasive technique to find the integrity of central auditory pathways through the VIIIth nerve, pons and midbrain

 

2. OAE is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by outer hair cells of a normal cochlea and can be elicited by a very sensitive microphone placed in the external ear canal and analyzed by a computer.

 

4. Tympanometry is an objective test for compliance or stiffness of the tympano-ossicular system. It evaluates the mobility of the eardrum (tympanic membrane) and the conduction bones of the middle ear, providing useful information about middle ear pressure and fluid presence.

 

Other Option:

 

3. PTA (pure tone audiometry): This is a subjective test as it relies on the patient's response to pure tone stimuli. It is not included as an objective test because it requires the patient's active participation to indicate when a sound is heard. Subjective tests such as PTA, tuning fork tests, and speech audiometry depend on patient interaction and are susceptible to voluntary or involuntary response errors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Objective hearing tests like BERA, OAE, and Tympanometry provide essential diagnostic information without the need for patient interaction, distinguishing them from subjective tests like Pure Tone Audiometry which rely on patient responses.

questions.text: A 32-year-old lady presented to the OPD with history of grittiness over both eyes for many years. Her Schirmer test value was found to be 5mm in both eyes. Which of the following treatment options can be given to her?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lubricants

 

The history of gritty sensation and Schirmer test 5mm (<10mm) is suggestive of a case of dry eye.

 

  • Lubricating eye drops, also called artificial tears, keep the conjunctiva moisturized. This helps to relieve discomfort secondary to dryness in the eyes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antihistaminic agent: Antihistaminic eye drops are used for allergic conjunctivitis and can exacerbate dry eye symptoms due to their drying effect on the ocular surface.

 

Option C. Antibiotic drops: These are not indicated in the absence of an infection. The patient's symptoms and Schirmer test results do not suggest an infectious cause.

 

Option D. Wait & watch: This approach is not appropriate as the patient has a confirmed diagnosis of dry eye which requires treatment to alleviate symptoms and prevent further ocular surface damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with dry eye disease, characterized by symptoms of grittiness and a Schirmer test value of less than 10mm, the primary treatment involves the use of lubricating eye drops to keep the conjunctiva moisturized and relieve discomfort.

questions.text:
What is the grade of tympanic membrane retraction shown in the image?

(INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
✅ Correct Answer: B. Grade 2

📸 Image Analysis:

The otoscopic image shows a retracted pars tensa where deeper middle ear structures like the long process of the incus and incudostapedial joint are visible. The lateral process of the malleus is prominently seen, and the tympanic membrane appears pulled medially, but it is not adherent to the promontory, and air is still visible in the middle ear. This presentation is typical of Grade 2 retraction.

🔍 Explanation of Options:

Option A: Grade 1

In Grade 1 pars tensa retraction, there is only mild inward retraction. The cone of light is lost, the fibrous annulus appears more prominent, and the handle of the malleus becomes more medialized. Importantly, there is no contact with the ossicles, and ossicular landmarks like the incus are not visible. This does not match the findings seen in the image.

 

Option B: Grade 2

Grade 2 retraction is more severe than Grade 1, and the pars tensa is retracted to the extent that it touches the long process of the incus. Deeper structures like the incudostapedial joint, round window niche, and even the horizontal facial canal may be visible. The tympanic membrane still retains some mobility and is not adherent to the promontory. This fits the otoscopic image exactly, where ossicular structures are seen but no signs of complete adhesion are present.

 

Option C: Grade 3

In Grade 3 retraction, the tympanic membrane is severely retracted and becomes adherent to the promontory, forming what is called an atelectatic membrane. Although some air may still remain in the middle ear, the drum is essentially collapsed onto the medial wall. This condition is more advanced than what is seen in the current image.

 

Option D: Grade 4

This is the most severe stage where the entire tympanic membrane is stuck to the promontory, and there is complete loss of middle ear aeration. It often leads to adhesive otitis media, and ossicular erosion (such as necrosis of the incus) may occur. This is clearly not the case here, as ossicles are intact and the membrane is not fully adherent.

🧠 Educational Objective:

Grade 2 pars tensa retraction is identified when the tympanic membrane retracts to touch the long process of the incus without adhering to the promontory, often revealing middle ear ossicles such as the incudostapedial joint.

questions.text: A post-COVID patient, who is a known diabetic, develops unilateral facial pain and loosening of teeth. Which investigation would you do to confirm the diagnosis on this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biopsy with histopathologic examination

 

The given scenario of a post-COVID diabetic patient with facial pain and loosening of teeth is suggestive of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis. Among the given options, Biopsy with histopathologic examination would be the investigation for definitive diagnosis on this patient.

 

The primary reason that appears to be facilitating Mucorales spores to germinate in people with COVID-19 is

 

  1.  An ideal environment of low oxygen (hypoxia)
  2. high glucose (diabetes, new-onset hyperglycemia, steroid-induced hyperglycemia)
  3. Acidic medium (metabolic acidosis, diabetic ketoacidosis [DKA])
  4. High iron levels (increased ferritins)
  5. Decreased phagocytic activity of white blood cells (WBC) due to immunosuppression (SARS-CoV-2 mediated, steroid-mediated or background comorbidities) coupled with several other shared risk factors including prolonged hospitalization with or without mechanical ventilators

 

Rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis is the most common form of mucormycosis. It commonly occurs in patients with diabetes mellitus.

 

The presenting features are facial pain, numbness, loosening of teeth, conjunctival swelling, congestion, and blurry vision. When the disease spreads to the orbit, proptosis can be present. Due to invasion of the blood vessels, mucor fungus causes ischemic necrosis presenting as a black eschar, involving inferior turbinate, palate or the sinus. It can later spread to the frontal lobe of the brain and cavernous sinus.

 

 

 

Confirmation of diagnosis is by biopsy and histopathologic examination which shows aseptate fungi with thick-walled, ribbon-like, hyphae branching at right angles.

 

 

MRI is more sensitive to detecting orbital and nervous involvement than CT.

 

Contrast-enhanced MRI is the imaging technique of choice – black turbinate sign is seen

 

 

Post-contrast T1-weighted coronal MR image shows non enhancing soft tissue, “black turbinate sign,” within the left maxillary sinus (asterisk). The mucosa of the inferior turbinate and a portion of the left middle turbinate demonstrate focal lack of the enhancement (arrowheads).

 

Management

 

  • Antifungal therapy with Amphotericin B
  •  Surgical debridement of the affected tissues.
  •  Treatment of underlying cause
  • Control of blood sugars in diabetic patients

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): Useful for assessing the extent of disease, especially in identifying orbital and central nervous system involvement. It provides detailed images that help in planning the extent of surgical debridement.

 

Option C. Serum Ferritin: Elevated ferritin levels are commonly seen in mucormycosis due to the fungus’s use of iron from the host, which aids its growth. While not diagnostic, high ferritin levels can support the suspicion of mucormycosis in the right clinical context.

 

Option D. HbA1c (Glycated Hemoglobin): This test reflects long-term glucose control and is crucial in managing diabetic patients. Although it does not diagnose mucormycosis, poor glycemic control indicated by a high HbA1c value is a risk factor for the development of fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early diagnosis and aggressive treatment are critical for patients suspected of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis, especially in those with risk factors like diabetes and a recent COVID-19 infection. A biopsy with histopathologic examination is essential for confirming the diagnosis. This condition requires a multidisciplinary approach involving antifungal therapy, surgical debridement, and meticulous management of underlying conditions like diabetes to prevent serious complications and improve outcomes.

questions.text: What is the most frequently observed fungal infection in the maxillary sinus among the options listed below? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Aspergillosis

 

Aspergillosis and Mucormycosis are the most common fungal infections that involve the maxillary sinuses.

 

Aspergillosis in the sinus typically manifests as either a non-invasive form (sinus aspergilloma or fungal ball) or an invasive form, which is more severe and occurs primarily in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Treatment - Surgical debridement of the involved tissues and antifungal drugs like Amphotericin-B. Repeated irrigation of the involved area with application of 1% solution of gentian violet is also useful.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blastomycosis: Typically affects the lungs and skin more frequently than the sinuses. It is more common in regions around the Ohio and Mississippi River valleys.

 

Option C. Candidiasis: While Candida species can infect mucosal surfaces, they rarely cause sinus infections compared to Aspergillus.

 

Option D. Histoplasmosis: Like blastomycosis, histoplasmosis primarily affects the lungs and is endemic to certain areas in the United States. It is not commonly seen in the sinuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspergillosis is the most prevalent fungal infection of the maxillary sinus among the choices provided. Recognizing the form of aspergillosis (non-invasive vs. invasive) is crucial for effective management, which can range from local care and antifungals to more aggressive surgical interventions depending on the case severity and patient's immune status.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient came with complaints of sudden onset ocular pain and haemorrhagic discharge accompanied with diminution of vision. He is suspected to have acute haemorrhagic conjunctivitis. What is the causative organism? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Enterovirus 70

 

Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis is caused by enterovirus 70, a picornavirus.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enterovirus 68: Known to cause respiratory illnesses and has been associated with acute flaccid myelitis, but not typically with hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

 

Option B. Enterovirus 69: Less commonly associated with conjunctivitis and more related to respiratory infections.

 

Option D. Enterovirus 71: Known to cause hand, foot, and mouth disease and severe neurological diseases, but not typically associated with hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enterovirus 70 is the primary causative organism of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, characterized by sudden onset of ocular pain, redness, and hemorrhagic discharge. The condition is highly contagious and typically self-limiting, with supportive care being the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text: Upon examining the CT image provided, a patient with a prior history of trauma is exhibiting symptoms such as diplopia, epistaxis, and limited eye movements. Given this clinical presentation, what would be your diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Blow out fracture

 

The image displayed above depicts a fractured floor of the left orbit.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Le-Fort Fracture: Involves complex fractures of the midface but usually presents with more extensive facial deformity and mobility.

 

Option B. Fracture Maxilla: This would involve more of the upper jaw and would likely present with significant swelling, malocclusion, and possibly involvement of the nasal septum and upper teeth.

 

Option C. Fracture Zygomatic: Involves the cheekbone; while it can cause eye symptoms due to proximity, it would typically also present with cheek deformity and pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient presenting with diplopia, limited eye movements, and epistaxis following facial trauma, a blow out fracture should be strongly considered. Early diagnosis using CT imaging and appropriate surgical consultation are critical to manage the condition effectively to prevent long-term visual and sensory complications.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image. (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adenoid facies

 

The above given image shows adenoid facies. The characteristic features are visible which are: -

 

  • Elongated face with dull expression
  • Open mouth
  • Hitched up upper lip
  • Prominent upper teeth, which appear crowded
  • High arched hard palate
  • Pinched-in nose

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Goldenhar syndrome: Typically presents with abnormalities of the eye, ear, and spine, none of which are visible in this image.

 

Option C. Horse facies: Characterized by an elongated face with prominent jaw structures, which does not match the features in the image.

 

Option D. Frog facies: Often includes a wide mouth and bulging eyes, which are not present in this child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoid facies can be recognized by characteristic features such as elongated face, open mouth posture due to nasal obstruction, hitched up upper lip revealing crowded upper teeth, and a pinched-in nose. It's associated with chronic adenoid hypertrophy, impacting the facial structure and respiratory function.

questions.text: Following total thyroidectomy, a patient started having difficulty in breathing, and repeated attempts to extubate were unsuccessful. The most probable cause is: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury

 

The clinical picture is suggestive of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.

 

Bilateral recurrent laryngeal injury is commonly seen in total thyroidectomy.

 

  • Injury to both RLNs results in paralysis of intrinsic muscles of the larynx. The vocal cords cannot be abducted and thus come to lie in a median or paramedian position due to unopposed action of cricothyroid. This results in compromised laryngeal airway causing respiratory distress and stridor.
  • Tracheostomy is done as an emergency procedure to secure the airway.
  • Widening the respiratory airway without a permanent tracheostomy can be achieved by:
    1. Transverse cordotomy (Kashima operation)
    2. Partial arytenoidectomy
    3. Reinnervation procedures - these are used to innervate paralyzed posterior cricoarytenoid muscle by implanting a nerve-muscle pedicle of sternohyoid or omohyoid muscle with its nerve supply from ansa hypoglossi.
    4.  Thyroplasty type II – lateralisation of vocal cords

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Superior laryngeal nerve injury - This would primarily affect voice pitch and not typically cause significant breathing difficulty.

 

Option B. Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury - Would lead to hoarseness but not usually severe breathing issues as one vocal cord would still function.

 

Option D. Hematoma - Although it can cause acute respiratory distress if it compresses the trachea, it does not typically lead to issues with extubation unless it is very severe.

 

Educational Objective:


Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury after thyroidectomy is a serious complication that can lead to life-threatening airway obstruction. Immediate recognition and management are crucial to ensure the safety and recovery of the patient.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 339

questions.text: A patient presented to the emergency department with complaints of monocular diplopia following blunt trauma to the eye. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Iridodialysis

 

Monocular diplopia following blunt trauma to the eye is suggestive of a disruption or separation of the iris from its normal position, known as iridodialysis. This condition can result from trauma and may cause double vision due to irregularities in the shape of the pupil. Iridodialysis is the disinsertion of the iris from the scleral spur. It is in contrast from cyclodialysis, which is disinsertion of the ciliary body from the scleral spur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rosette cataract: This type of cataract can form after blunt trauma but typically causes a reduction in vision rather than monocular diplopia. The lens opacity in a rosette pattern does not generally cause the type of diplopia described.

 

Option C. Retinal detachment: Presents with symptoms such as flashes of light, floaters, and a shadow or curtain over part of the visual field. It does not typically cause monocular diplopia.

 

Option D. Corneal injury: While corneal injuries can cause visual disturbances and sometimes double vision, they are more likely to present with pain, redness, and tearing. They usually do not result in the specific monocular diplopia seen with iridodialysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Monocular diplopia following blunt trauma to the eye is highly suggestive of iridodialysis, which is the disinsertion of the iris from the scleral spur, leading to an irregular pupil shape and resultant visual disturbances.

questions.text: The image given shows a patient who has undergone total laryngectomy due to laryngeal cancer. Identify the method of voice generation for this patient, as depicted in the provided image.(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tracheoesophageal prosthesis

 

The voice production modality depicted in the image is tracheoesophageal voice prosthesis.

 

The extended air from the trachea is diverted to the esophagus through a device that connects the trachea and esophagus in tracheoesophageal prosthesis. It also has a one-way valve that keeps food from entering into the trachea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electrolarynx: Is a vibrating instrument that emits a low-pitched sound in the hypopharynx. The palate, tongue, and teeth then articulate it.

 

Option B. Chicago implant: Is a type of hearing aid.

 

Option D. Esophageal speech: The patient is trained to swallow air and slowly release it into the pharynx. 6-10 words can be spoken in a rough manner before re-swallowing the air.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tracheoesophageal prosthesis is a common and effective method for voice restoration following total laryngectomy. It relies on a surgically implanted device that directs air into the esophagus where vibrations are created for speech, significantly enhancing the quality of life for patients who have lost their natural voice box.

questions.text: An adult man in a restaurant suddenly begins choking on his food. He is conscious. The following procedure was performed. Identify the procedure: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Heimlich’s maneuver

 

The image shows a Heimlich's maneuver

 

First aid for foreign body in the airway -

 

A large bolus of food obstructed above the cords may make the patient totally aphonic, unable to cry for help. He may die of asphyxia unless immediate first aid measures are taken.

 

The first aid measures consist of pounding on the back, turning the patient upside down and following Heimlich maneuver. These measures should not be done if the patient is only partially obstructed, for fear of causing total obstruction.

 

Heimlich maneuver. - Stand behind the person and place your arms around his lower chest and give four abdominal thrusts. The residual air in the lungs may dislodge the foreign body providing some airway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Back Slaps: Before attempting the Heimlich maneuver, delivering five firm back slaps between the individual's shoulder blades can be tried as this may dislodge the item.

 

Option C. Chest Thrusts: Used instead of abdominal thrusts in cases where the Heimlich might be risky, such as in very obese or pregnant individuals.

 

Option D. Blind Finger Sweeps: Not recommended due to the risk of pushing the object deeper into the throat, potentially worsening the blockage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Heimlich maneuver is an effective emergency procedure for saving lives in cases of severe choking. It is important for everyone to learn this technique as it can be performed on others or even on oneself in a choking emergency.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 367

questions.text: What is the causative organism of angular conjunctivitis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Moraxella lacunata

 

  • Moraxella species are gram-negative diplococci that can cause angular conjunctivitis.
  • Angular conjunctivitis is characterized by inflammation of the inner and outer canthi, skin excoriation, and a collection of dirty-white, foamy discharge at the angles.
  • Moraxella axenfeld, Moraxella lacunata, and Moraxella catarrhalis are common causes of angular conjunctivitis, while Staphylococcus aureus is a rare cause.
  • The source of infection is the nasal tract of healthy people and the nasal discharge of patients with angular conjunctivitis.
  • The infection spreads from the nasal cavity to the eye through contaminated hands and handkerchiefs.
  • Oxytetracycline is the preferred treatment for angular conjunctivitis, with a duration of 10 to 14 days.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Haemophilus influenzae: While this organism can cause bacterial conjunctivitis, it is not specifically associated with angular conjunctivitis.

 

Option C. Adenovirus type 32: Adenoviruses can cause viral conjunctivitis, including epidemic keratoconjunctivitis, but they are not the typical cause of angular conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Coxsackie B virus: This virus can cause viral infections including conjunctivitis, but it is not the usual causative agent for angular conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary causative organism of angular conjunctivitis is Moraxella lacunata, which is a gram-negative diplococci. The infection spreads from the nasal cavity to the eyes through contaminated hands and handkerchiefs, and is characterized by inflammation of the canthi and a dirty-white, foamy discharge. The preferred treatment is oxytetracycline for 10 to 14 days.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient, who is a known case of diabetes mellitus since the past 25 years, came for a health checkup. He was found to have uncontrolled blood sugar levels and third cranial nerve palsy. Which is the most common feature of third nerve palsy seen in such a case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ptosis

 

  • Diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy is caused by hyperglycemia-induced damage to nerve cells and neuronal ischemic change.
  • The arrangement of the fibers in the third cranial nerve is such that the fibers controlling the pupillary reflex are superficial and often spared from diabetic ischemia-induced injury.
  • Pupillary dysfunction is not commonly present in diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy.
  • The levator palpebrae superiors and most of the oculomotor muscles, except for the lateral rectus and superior oblique, are damaged in diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy.
  • Diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy typically presents with ptosis and diplopia.

 

APPLIED ANATOMY OF PUPILLOMOTOR NERVE FIBRES

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proptosis: Protrusion of the eye, not typically associated with diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

Option B. Pseudoptosis: False appearance of ptosis, not related to actual muscle dysfunction.

 

Option D. Pupillary dysfunction: Although part of the oculomotor nerve's function, it is usually spared in diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy due to the peripheral location of the pupillary fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid) is the most common feature of third nerve palsy seen in diabetic patients, due to the selective ischemic damage to the central fibers of the oculomotor nerve, sparing the peripheral pupillary fibers.

questions.text: What are the air cells located at the anterior most part of the anterior ethmoidal sinus called?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Agger nasi

 

The Agger nasi cells are the anterior-most air cells of the anterior ethmoid air cells. They are situated just above the attachment of the middle turbinate, making them critical landmarks in sinus surgery due to their proximity to the frontal sinus drainage pathway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bulla ethmoidalis largest air cells in ethmoidal air sinus

 

Option B. Onodi cell/ Sphenoethmoidal air cell is the posterior most ethmoidal air cell. They are significant due to their proximity to the optic nerve and the sphenoid sinus, posing a risk during sinus surgery.

 

 

Option D. Haller cell/ infraorbital ethmoidal air cells are ethmoid air cells located lateral to the maxillo-ethmoidal suture along the inferomedial orbital floor. Haller cells can impact the drainage of the maxillary sinus and are important to consider in imaging and surgical planning for sinus issues.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Agger nasi is the anterior-most air cells of anterior ethmoid air cells.
  • Bulla ethmoidalis is the largest air cells in ethmoidal air sinus
  • Onodi cell/ Sphenoethmoidal air cell is the posterior most ethmoidal air cells
  • Haller cells are ethmoid air cells that extend into the floor of the orbit and can affect the integrity and drainage of the maxillary sinus

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 152, 153

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of hearing loss and can understand only shouted or amplified speech. What would be the degree of impairment according to the WHO classification of ability to understand speech? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Severe hearing loss

Severe hearing loss means that individuals cannot hear most conversations. They typically only hear very loud sounds, such as a raised voice or sounds above 61 to 80 dB. They may not understand speech at normal levels and usually require powerful hearing aids or cochlear implants to assist their hearing. These individuals may rely more on lip reading or sign language.

Other Options:

Option A. Mild hearing loss: Individuals with mild hearing loss typically have difficulty understanding speech, especially in noisy situations. The hearing loss ranges between 26 and 40 decibels (dB). They can usually hear well in one-to-one conversations and might only struggle in noisier environments.

Option B. Moderate hearing loss: With moderate hearing loss, individuals have difficulty understanding regular speech, even at close distances. The hearing loss is between 41 and 60 dB. They often require some form of hearing assistance for daily activities and may benefit significantly from hearing aids.

Option D. Profound hearing loss: Profound hearing loss indicates that individuals cannot hear any speech and only very loud sounds exceeding 81 dB, such as that from heavy machinery or loud horns. Conversational speech is not audible at all. Persons with profound hearing loss rely on visual communication methods like sign language and may be candidates for cochlear implants.

Educational Objective: 

The case scenario described above points towards Severe hearing loss in the patient.

questions.text: Which of the following features will not be manifested in an infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space?(AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trismus

 

  • Trismus is not a feature of infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space.
  • Parapharyngeal space is divided into 2 compartments by styloid process & its attachments. Clinical features depend on the compartment involved.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vocal cord palsy: This could manifest due to involvement of the cranial nerves (CN IX, X, XI, XII) that are located in the post-styloid compartment. CN X (vagus nerve) palsy particularly can lead to vocal cord paralysis.

 

Option C. Parotid swelling: Swelling in this region may occur as the post-styloid compartment is adjacent to the parotid gland and includes inflammatory processes that might extend into the parotid space.

 

Option D. Horner's syndrome: This syndrome may appear if the sympathetic chain, which runs through the post-styloid compartment, is affected by an infection or its related inflammatory processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Presentation in a post-styloid abscess:

 

Bulge behind posterior tonsillar pillar.

 

  • Since post styloid compartment contains CN IX, X, XI, XII, their palsies may be seen.
  • Sympathetic chain involvement in this compartment will cause Horner's syndrome.
  • Swelling of the parotid region
  • No trismus or minimal trismus
  • General Symptoms - Fever, odynophagia, sore throat, torticollis (due to spasm of prevertebral muscles) and signs of toxemia

 

Diagnosis

 

  • Contrast-enhanced CT scan neck – for extent of a lesion.
  • Magnetic resonance arteriography is useful if thrombosis of the internal jugular vein or aneurysm of the internal carotid artery is suspected.

 

Treatment

 

  • IV antibiotics with aerobic and anaerobic cover
  • Incision and drainage of abscess

questions.text: Which of the following would be prescribed for simple myopic astigmatism?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. -1.00 DC X 180 degree

 

  • The correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism is -1.00 DC × 180 degrees.
  • Simple myopic astigmatism means that one principal meridian of the eye is in focus on the retina, while the other principal meridian is in front of the retina.
  • There are three components to the prescription of glasses for astigmatism: 
    1. The power of the spherical component (convex or concave dioptre sphere),
    2. The power of the cylinder (convex or concave dioptre cylinder),
    3. The axis (orientation) of the cylinder.

 

For example: -1.00 DC × 180 degree

 

This prescription indicates that the individual has simple astigmatism, which means one meridian of the eye is in focus while the other is not. In this case, the unfocused meridian is myopic (nearsighted) and requires correction with a concave cylinder lens. The strength of the cylinder lens is -1.00 diopters (DC). The axis of the cylinder is oriented at 180 degrees, which represents the meridian that is most affected by astigmatism.

 

Types of astigmatism:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. +1.00 DS: This represents a convex spherical lens for hypermetropia (farsightedness) and is not used for astigmatism correction.

 

Option C. -1.00 DS: This represents a concave spherical lens for simple myopia (nearsightedness) but does not correct astigmatism.

 

Option D. -1.00 DS -1.00 DC X 180 degree: This represents a prescription for compound myopic astigmatism, where both meridians are myopic, one corrected by the spherical component and the other by the cylindrical component.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Simple myopic astigmatism requires correction with a cylindrical lens that corrects the myopic meridian, typically specified with the cylinder power and the axis. The correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism in this case is -1.00 DC X 180 degrees.

questions.text: Lateral view radiograph is best used to visualize which of the following sinuses? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sphenoid sinus

 

Explanation:

 

Lateral view radiograph is particularly useful for visualizing the sphenoid sinus because:

  • Shows the anterior and posterior walls of the sphenoid sinus clearly
  • Demonstrates the relationship with sella turcica
  • Reveals the size and pneumatization of the sphenoid sinus
  • Can show fluid levels if present
  • Helps assess the sphenoid sinus walls for erosion

 

The lateral view provides a profile projection where:

  • The sphenoid sinus is seen in the center of the skull base
  • The sella turcica forms its roof
  • The clivus forms its floor
  • Both anterior and posterior walls are clearly visible

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maxillary sinus: Best visualized in Water's/occipitomental view

 

Option B. Ethmoidal sinus: Better visualized in CT scan or Caldwell view

 

Option D. Frontal sinus: Though visible on lateral view, is better visualized in Caldwell view

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the appropriate radiographic views for different paranasal sinuses is crucial for accurate diagnosis. The lateral view's ability to show the sphenoid sinus in profile makes it particularly valuable for evaluating this deep-seated structure.

questions.text: Investigation of choice for JNA? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CECT

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a highly vascular tumor found in adolescent males. The investigation of choice for JNA is Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography (CECT). CECT is preferred because it effectively delineates the bony margins and the extent of the tumor, including any bone erosion. The contrast enhancement helps in identifying the vascular nature of the tumor, which is crucial in differentiating JNA from other masses in the nasal cavity, such as adenoids or carcinomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI: MRI is helpful for assessing orbital and cranial extensions of the tumor but is not the primary choice for initial diagnosis. It does not provide as clear an image of the bony structures as CECT does.

 

Option C. DNE (Diagnostic Nasal Endoscopy): While DNE can visualize a mass in the nasal cavity, it cannot determine the type of mass or its vascular nature. It is less informative than imaging studies in the diagnosis of JNA.

 

Option D. Biopsy: Biopsy is contraindicated in suspected JNA due to the high risk of severe bleeding given the vascular nature of the tumor. Attempting a biopsy can lead to significant complications.

 

Educational Objective:


The investigation of choice for diagnosing Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma is CECT due to its ability to define the tumor's vascularity and extent while safely avoiding the complications associated with biopsy

questions.text: A female patient presents with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and loss of smell. On examination, foul-smelling discharge and yellowish-green crusts are present in the nasal cavity. She is found to have merciful anosmia. Which of the following finding can also be seen during the examination of her nose? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Roomy nasal cavity

 

ATROPHIC RHINITIS:

 

Pathology - Ciliated columnar epithelium is lost and is replaced by stratified squamous type. There is atrophy of seromucinous glands, venous blood sinusoids and nerve elements. Arteries in the mucosa, periosteum and bone show obliterative endarteritis. The bone of turbinates undergoes resorption causing widening of nasal chambers. Paranasal sinuses are small due to their arrested development.

 

Clinical Features

 

  1. Commonly seen in females and starts around puberty
  2. Foul smell from the nose though the patient himself is unaware of the smell due to marked anosmia (merciful anosmia) which accompanies these degenerative changes.
  3. Patients may complain of nasal obstruction due to large crusts filling the nose.
  4. Epistaxis may occur when the crusts are removed.

 

On examination shows

 

  1. Nasal cavity to be full of greenish or grayish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum. Attempts to remove them may cause bleeding.
  2. When the crusts have been removed, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates.
  3. Nasal mucosa appears pale. Septal perforation and dermatitis of nasal vestibule may be present. Nose may show a saddle deformity.
  4.  Atrophic changes may also be seen in the pharyngeal mucosa larynx.
  5. Hearing impairment may be noticed because of obstruction to the eustachian tube and middle ear effusion.
  6. Paranasal sinuses are usually small and underdeveloped with thick walls.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Nasal irrigation - using warm saline or an alkaline solution composed of sodium bicarbonate 1 part, sodium biborate 1 part, sodium chloride 2 parts in 280 mL of water
  • Local antibiotics - Kemicetine antiozaena solution containing chloromycetin, estradiol, and vitamin D2.
  • 25% glucose in glycerine, estradiol spray, systemic use of streptomycin, potassium iodide, placental extract.

 

Surgical management:

 

  • Young's operation: In this procedure, flaps are raised within the nasal vestibule and both the nostrils are completely closed and are opened after 6 months. During this time, the mucosa may revert to normal and the crusting is reduced.
  • Modified young's operation: In this procedure, the nostrils are partially closed and thereby avoiding the discomfort from complete closure of the nostrils. The results are the same compared to Young's operation.
  • Narrowing of the nasal cavity can be done by submucosal injection of Teflon paste, or by insertion of fat, cartilage, or Teflon strips under the mucoperiosteum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nasal polyps: These are non-neoplastic masses of the edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. Nasal polyps can be antrochoanal polyps or ethmoidal polyps.

 

Option C. Inferior turbinate hypertrophy: It is associated with various mucosal diseases which include allergic rhinitis, infectious rhinitis, and vasomotor rhinitis. It can cause chronic nasal obstruction.

 

Option D. Foreign body nose: It is commonly seen in children and the child presents with unilateral, foul-smelling nasal discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrophic rhinitis leads to significant structural changes within the nasal cavity, most notably an enlargement of the space due to bone and soft tissue atrophy. Recognizing these changes is crucial for diagnosing and managing the condition effectively, with treatments often focusing on moisturizing the nasal cavity and addressing the underlying atrophic changes.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 172, 173

questions.text: A 7-year-old child post-tonsillectomy comes to you with complaints of snoring, palpitations, mouth breathing and a slight decrease in hearing. On examination, you notice a high arched palate. His school performance is deteriorating as well. His mother is worried. What is the next line of management for this child?(FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion

 

The child's symptoms suggest the presence of adenoid hypertrophy, which is contributing to eustachian tube dysfunction, leading to serous otitis media. This condition can result in conductive hearing loss, which may be contributing to his school performance issues. Additionally, the presence of snoring and mouth breathing indicates that the adenoids may be sufficiently enlarged to obstruct the airway, particularly during sleep.

 

Next Steps in Management: Adenoidectomy with Grommet Insertion: This surgical intervention is recommended to address both the adenoid hypertrophy and the associated middle ear effusion. Removing the adenoids can help open up the airway and improve nasal breathing, while grommet insertion (myringotomy with tube placement) helps ventilate the middle ear and prevent fluid accumulation, improving hearing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoidectomy Alone: While this would address the nasal obstruction, it might not adequately resolve the middle ear effusion without the addition of grommets.

 

Option B. Myringoplasty: This is a repair procedure for a perforated eardrum, not relevant to this case as the main issue is middle ear effusion, not tympanic membrane perforation.

 

Option D. Conservative Management: Given the impact on the child’s hearing and school performance, plus the physical symptoms, conservative management would likely be insufficient in providing relief.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the finding shown in the figure characteristic of? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Viral keratitis

 

The figure shows dendritic ulcers that are seen in viral keratitis.

They are irregular, linear branching ulcers with knobbed ends and reduced corneal sensations.

 

Viral Ulcer

 

It can be caused by Herpes simplex virus (most common), Varicella zoster virus and Adenovirus. Pathognomic feature of viral corneal ulcer is decrease in corneal sensations.

 

Herpes simplex keratitis

 

Man is the only natural host for this DNA virus. It can be the following types:

 

  1. Primary herpes: It is usually caused by primary infection in non-immunized children. The features include vesicular skin lesions, follicular conjunctivitis or keratitis (usually affect epithelium only).
  2. Secondary herpes: It is due to reactivation of a dormant (latent) virus in the trigeminal nerve ganglion. It causes decrease in corneal sensations. It can affect either the epithelium or the stroma.

 

  • Epithelial keratitis: It manifests as dendritic ulcer or geographical ulcer (large ‘amoeboid’ ulcer). Steroids cause progression of dendritic ulcer into geographical ulcer, so, they are contraindicated. The treatment is done with 3% acyclovir ointment and mechanical debridement.
  • Stromal keratitis: It manifests as disciform keratitis (disc shaped ulcer with a surrounding Wessley immune ring formed due to delayed hypersensitivity to HSV antigen) or diffuse stromal necrotic keratitis (due to active viral invasion and tissue destruction). The treatment is steroid drops with acyclovir 3%.

 

 

Dendritic corneal ulcer due to recurrent keratitis by Herpes Simplex Virus

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fungal keratitis: Typically presents with a feathery-edged corneal ulcer, satellite lesions, and hypopyon. It is not characterized by dendritic ulcers.

 

Option C. Bacterial keratitis: Presents with a round, well-demarcated ulcer, often with hypopyon and severe pain. Dendritic patterns are not seen.

 

Option D. Acanthamoeba keratitis: Typically presents with severe pain, perineural infiltrates, and ring infiltrates. It is associated with contact lens use and does not present with dendritic ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dendritic ulcers are a hallmark of viral keratitis, particularly Herpes simplex keratitis, and are characterized by their irregular, branching pattern and reduced corneal sensations.

choices.text: Nasal polyps with middle meatal widening

questions.text: A female patient presents with nasal obstruction, clear rhinorrhea, and sneezing episodes. On examination, there are multiple translucent grape-like masses visible in both nasal cavities. The patient reports loss of smell and tastes. Which of the following findings would also be seen during examination of her nose? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nasal polyps with middle meatal widening

 

Explanation: 

 

The clinical scenario suggests bilateral nasal polyposis because:

  • Presence of translucent grape-like masses is pathognomonic
  • Associated anosmia is due to mechanical obstruction and inflammatory damage
  • Clear rhinorrhea rather than foul discharge
  • Middle meatal widening is characteristic due to polyp origin from ethmoid region

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Roomy nasal cavity: Seen in atrophic rhinitis with crusting and foul smell 

 

Option C. Inferior turbinate hypertrophy: Though can cause obstruction, doesn't explain the grape-like masses 

 

Option D. Foreign body: Usually unilateral with purulent discharge

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nasal polyps are characterized by: 
    • Bilateral translucent masses
    • Origin from middle meatus/ethmoid region
    • Associated anosmia/hyposmia
    • Clear rhinorrhea rather than purulent discharge
  • Diagnostic features include: 
    • Middle meatal widening on examination
    • Typically bilateral and multiple
    • Respond to steroids
    • May need surgical intervention if medical management fails
  • Important to distinguish from unilateral masses which may have different pathology

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is exhibiting symptoms of a low-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and a barking cough that have persisted for the last 5 days. Upon examination, he displays a hoarse voice, a moderately inflamed pharynx, and a slightly elevated respiratory rate. The chest X-ray reveals subglottic narrowing, resembling a steeple shape. Among the listed treatment options, which one is NOT recommended for managing this condition? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Parenteral cefotaxime

 

The presence of the steeple sign on the x-ray indicates a diagnosis of croup (laryngotracheobronchitis).

 

However, it is important to note that parenteral cefotaxime (antibiotic) is not recommended for its treatment as the causative organisms are most commonly viral.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nebulized Racemic Epinephrine: Recommended in severe cases of croup for its ability to reduce swelling in the airway and improve symptoms quickly.

 

Option C. Helium Oxygen Mixture (Heliox): Used to ease the work of breathing in severe cases of croup by reducing airway resistance.

 

Option D. Intramuscular Dexamethasone: A corticosteroid that reduces airway inflammation and is a standard treatment for croup to alleviate symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with painless cervical lymphadenopathy. During the examination, the right ear shows conductive hearing loss, and the tympanic membrane appears dull. Additionally, reduced mobility of the soft palate is noted. What could be the likely diagnosis for these findings?(FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

 

Given clinical condition is suggestive of Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adenoid cystic cancer: Typically involves salivary glands, not commonly associated with the described ear and nasopharyngeal symptoms.

 

Option C. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Mostly affects adolescent males and is a benign tumor, which would not usually present with the described range of symptoms including lymphadenopathy.

 

Option D. Quinsy: Refers to a peritonsillar abscess, primarily presenting with severe throat pain, unilateral sore throat, fever, and difficulty swallowing, differing significantly from the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a serious condition requiring prompt diagnosis and comprehensive treatment, given its potential for significant morbidity due to local invasion and distant metastasis. The clinical findings provided are strongly indicative of this diagnosis and warrant further confirmatory diagnostics, such as imaging and biopsy, followed by an appropriate oncological treatment regimen.

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 284,285

questions.text: A patient who is a primipara is experiencing an aggravation of hearing impairment during her pregnancy. Rinne's test yields negative results in both ears, and Weber's test indicates lateralization to the right side. Upon otoscopy, the tympanic membranes appear normal. Audiometry reveals a dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz. What treatment would be most suitable for this particular condition? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Stapedotomy

 

The given clinical presentation strongly indicates otosclerosis as the diagnosis, and the preferred treatment for this condition is stapedotomy an effective surgical treatment for otosclerosis, often preferred over stapedectomy due to a lower risk of complications and similar efficacy in restoring hearing

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sodium fluoride: Once a common medical treatment for otosclerosis, though now largely considered obsolete due to less satisfactory long-term outcomes compared to surgical interventions.

 

Option B. Tympanoplasty: This procedure is used to reconstruct the tympanic membrane and middle ear ossicles but is not indicated for otosclerosis, which does not typically affect the tympanic membrane integrity.

 

Option C. Stapedectomy: surgical treatment for otosclerosis, but less preferred over stapedotomy due to high risk of complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with otosclerosis, especially during pregnancy, stapedotomy is the recommended treatment to address conductive hearing loss effectively. These surgical options are typically preferred over medical management with sodium fluoride due to better auditory outcomes and more definitive resolution of conductive hearing impairments.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl with myopia started using her elder sister’s contact lenses. This sharing of contact lens may lead to the spread of which of the following infections? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
