Ans. B) Acanthamoeba

 

  • A history of contact lens misuse indicates an infection by Acanthamoeba.
  • Acanthamoeba has a great affinity for the attachment to the corneal epithelium and to contact lenses. The tendency for Acanthamoeba to adhere to surfaces is a key first step in the pathogenesis of Acanthamoeba keratitis, particularly in contact lens wearers.
  • Contact lenses affect corneal epithelium integrity in two different ways: 
    1. Directly, through the associated fitting-related abrasions and
    2. Indirectly, by altering the normal physiological and metabolic cellular activities.
  • These changes later render the epithelial cells in a hypoxic status that eventually alters their integrity. Corneal oxygenation is significantly reduced during contact lens overwear, particularly for those who sleep in their lenses overnight. 
  • However, patient's compliance and some basic hygienic standards can effectively minimise the risk of Acanthamoeba keratitis.

 

Features:

  • Intense ocular pain
  • Ring abscess
  • Pseudodendrites

 

Drug of choice: Polyhexamethylene Biguanide (PHMB)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidiasis: Typically affects immunocompromised patients and is less commonly associated with contact lens use.

 

Option C. Viral infection: While viral infections can occur with poor contact lens hygiene, they are less commonly associated with the specific scenario of contact lens sharing.

 

Option D. Damage of lens: This option refers to a physical condition of the lens rather than an infection. The primary concern with contact lens misuse is the risk of infection rather than lens damage.

 

Educational Objective:


Sharing contact lenses can lead to Acanthamoeba keratitis, an infection characterized by intense ocular pain and ring abscesses, due to the organism's affinity for attaching to the corneal epithelium and contact lenses.

questions.text: A patient presents with the complaint of inability to close the eye, drooling of saliva, and deviation of the angle of the mouth. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be affected? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Facial nerve

 

The given clinical features of inability to close the eye, drooling of saliva, and deviation of the angle of the mouth are suggestive of paralysis of the facial nerve.

 

Bell's palsy is defined as idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis or paresis of acute onset.

 

Etiology –

 

  1. Viral infection  - herpes simplex, herpes zoster, EBV
  2. Vascular ischemia
  3. Heredity – narrow fallopian canal
  4. Autoimmune

 

Clinical features -

 

Onset is sudden. Patient is unable to close his eyes. On attempting to close the eye, the eyeball turns up and out (Bell phenomenon). Saliva dribbles from the angle of mouth. Face becomes asymmetrical. Tears flow down from the eye (epiphora). Pain in the ear may precede or accompany nerve paralysis. Some complain of noise intolerance (stapedial paralysis) or loss of taste (involvement of chorda tympani). Paralysis may be complete or incomplete. Bell palsy is recurrent in 3–10% of patients.

 

 

Bell's palsy is a diagnosis of exclusion. All other possible causes of facial paralysis should be ruled out by investigations.

 

Treatment of Bell's palsy -

 

  • Prednisolone is the drug of choice. If a patient reports within 1 week, the adult dose of prednisolone is 1 mg/kg/day divided into morning and evening doses for 5 days. Patient is seen on the fifth day. If paralysis is incomplete or is recovering, the dose is tapered during the next 5 days. If paralysis remains complete, the same dose is continued for another 10 days and thereafter tapered in next 5 days (total of 20 days).
  • Eye care to prevent keratitis
  • Analgesic for ear pain
  • Physiotherapy

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Trigeminal nerve: Mainly responsible for facial sensation, not motor control.

 

Option C. Oculomotor nerve: Primarily influences eye movement; paralysis typically results in ptosis and pupillary dilation, not facial drooping.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal nerve: Affects swallowing and taste sensations at the back of the tongue; does not cause facial drooping or affect eye closure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prompt recognition and treatment of facial nerve paralysis are crucial for improving outcomes and preventing permanent damage. Treatment primarily involves medication to reduce inflammation and supportive care, especially for eye protection.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 103, 104

questions.text: A child with a low socio-economic background presents with white spots in both the eyes in the temporal conjunctiva. On examination, conjunctival xerosis is also noted. Which of the following vitamins could be deficient in this child?(FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

 

The description given in the question is that of Bitot spots seen in vitamin A deficiency.

 

BITOT SPOT:

 

  • Xerosis of conjunctiva
  • Raised, silvery white
  • Foamy triangular patch
  • Usually bilateral & temporal
  • Sign of Vitamin A deficiency

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin D: Deficiency in Vitamin D primarily leads to rickets in children, which affects bone development and growth. It does not cause Bitot’s spots or conjunctival xerosis.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: Deficiency in Vitamin E can lead to neurological problems and hemolytic anemia but does not affect the conjunctiva or cause the signs described in the question.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12: Deficiency in Vitamin B12 primarily affects the hematological and nervous systems, causing conditions such as megaloblastic anemia and neuropathy. It does not cause conjunctival xerosis or Bitot’s spots.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Treatment Guidelines

 

Vitamin A therapy

questions.text: Which of these characteristics is not linked to superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome?(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sensorineural hearing loss

 

  • Conductive hearing loss is seen in superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome (SSCDS).
  • “Third window” mechanism due to SCD and enlarged vestibular aqueduct. Schematic representations illustrate inner ear volume velocity with arrows -
    1. Normal anatomy allows volume velocity across the cochlear partition from the oval to the round window (two windows).
    2. Air conducted sound stimulation results in volume velocity from the stapes to be shunted toward the SCD (third window) and away from the cochlea, resulting in increased air-conduction thresholds at low frequencies and/or sound-induced vertigo (Tullio's phenomenon). Positive static pressure in the middle-ear cavity may result in ampullofugal fluid motion exciting the ampulla, resulting in nystagmus (Hennebert sign) and oscillopsia/vertigo.
    3. Elevated intracranial pressure from Valsalva against closed glottis (e.g., straining, heaving lifting) may result in ampullopetal endolymphatic fluid motion, inhibition of the ampulla, also leading to nystagmus (Hennebert sign) and oscillopsia/vertigo.
    4. Enlarged vestibular aqueduct (EVA) can also act as a third window, shunting volume velocity away from the cochlear partition and toward the widened vestibular aqueduct.

 

Gaze-evoked tinnitus or hyperacusis may also be seen.

 

 

  • High-resolution CT is the gold standard for identification of SSCD
  • Cervical VEMP sensitivity and specificity for diagnosing SSCDS ranges from 80% to 100%
  • Surgery is indicated only if symptoms are severe and disabling. Otherwise managed conservatively with medication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gaze dependent nystagmus: This can occur in SSCDS due to the abnormal transmission of fluid pressure waves through the "third window" created by the dehiscence, affecting the balance organs in the inner ear.

 

Option B. Positive Fistula test: This test, which involves applying pressure to the ear canal, can produce eye movements (nystagmus) or vertigo in cases of SSCDS due to the abnormal transmission of pressure to the inner ear.

 

Option D. Positive Tullio's phenomenon: This refers to sound-induced vertigo or nystagmus, which is a hallmark of SSCDS. The phenomenon occurs because sound vibrations lead to abnormal fluid dynamics in the inner ear due to the dehiscence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In SSCDS, conductive hearing loss is typical due to the additional pathway for sound and pressure transmission created by the dehiscence, not sensorineural hearing loss, which involves damage to the hair cells in the cochlea or the auditory nerve. Understanding these distinct characteristics helps in accurately diagnosing and managing the condition.

 

Ref - Scott Brown 8th edition, volume 2, Page no. 843-847

questions.text:
Which of the following tests can be used if otoacoustic emissions is absent for screening?(INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Pure tone audiometry
  2. Tympanometry
  3. Free field audiometry
  4. Speech audiometry
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 and 4

 

When otoacoustic emissions (OAE) are absent, it indicates a potential cochlear pathology, specifically affecting the outer hair cells. Further testing is required to assess the extent and nature of hearing loss, as well as to rule out any retrocochlear pathology.

 

2. Tympanometry: This test assesses the condition of the middle ear and tympanic membrane mobility by creating variations in air pressure in the ear canal. It is useful to determine if the absence of OAEs might be related to middle ear issues, such as fluid, which can mask cochlear function.

 

4. Speech Audiometry: This test evaluates the ability to understand speech and also provides information about the clarity of speech perception. It helps to determine the speech recognition threshold and is crucial for diagnosing the degree and type of hearing loss when OAEs are absent.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Pure Tone Audiometry: While this test is crucial for determining the threshold levels of hearing and the degree of hearing loss across different frequencies, it was not specified as one of the correct responses in this context.

 

3. Free Field Audiometry: Generally used for young children or individuals who cannot reliably use headphones, this test measures hearing sensitivity to sounds presented in an open field. However, it requires a controlled sound field, which is not always practical for immediate follow-up when OAEs are absent.

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 29

questions.text: Following a surgical procedure on the lateral aspect of the skull base, the patient experiences postoperative aspiration. However, there is no alteration in the patient's voice. What could be the explanation for this?(AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Superior laryngeal nerve injury

 

  • The patient has an injury to the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN).
  • SLN motor supply – cricothyroid muscle → when affected causes change in voice only in high pitch
  • SLN sensory supply – Above level of vocal cords → when affected can cause aspiration.
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve doesn't provide either sensory or motor supply to the larynx so its lesion will not cause aspiration.
  • RLN supplies all the intrinsic muscles of the larynx except cricothyroid > when affected will cause change in voice.
  • A high vagal injury will affect both SLN and RLN, hence can also be ruled out.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glossopharyngeal nerve injury: This nerve does not primarily provide sensory or motor innervation to the larynx; its involvement would not typically result in aspiration.

 

Option C. Recurrent laryngeal nerve injury: Injury to this nerve would more likely affect the voice since it innervates all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid. It would lead to vocal cord paralysis.

 

Option D. High vagal injury: An injury here would affect both the SLN and the recurrent laryngeal nerve, likely causing symptoms in both voice and swallowing mechanisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Injury to the superior laryngeal nerve, particularly its internal branch, is a plausible explanation for the patient's aspiration post-surgery, especially when there is no accompanying change in voice quality. This suggests that the sensory function above the vocal cords is compromised, increasing the risk of aspiration without necessarily affecting voice modulation handled by the external laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: A neonate is brought to the OPD with complaints of redness and discharge from both the eyes, raising a suspicion of ophthalmia neonatorum. What is the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chlamydia

 

Explanation : 


Chlamydia is the most common bacterial cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries.


Ophthalmia neonatorum is a type of conjunctivitis seen in the neonatal period,  presenting  5-14 days after birth with red eyes and discharge. It commonly gets transmitted during vaginal delivery. Requires antibiotic treatment.

 


Other Options:

 

Option B. Gonorrhea: Severe, purulent conjunctivitis presenting 2-5 days after birth. It commonly gets transmitted during vaginal delivery, and it correlates with severe complications such as corneal ulceration and perforation, which can potentially result in permanent blindness. Requires Urgent antibiotic treatment.

 

Option C. Chemical conjunctivitis : occurs within 24 hrs , Caused by 1% AgNO3 Crede's method used to prevent ophthalmia neonatorum. Presents with mild inflammation, redness, and tearing, and usually resolves on its own.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus: Less common cause, presenting with mild to moderate redness and discharge. Treated with topical antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective: 
 

 

(REF: Matejcek A, Goldman RD. Treatment and prevention of ophthalmia neonatorum. Can Fam Physician. 2013 Nov;59(11):1187-90. PMID: 24235191; PMCID: PMC3828094.)

choices.text: Increase in the size of capsule covering the diameter

questions.text: Which of the following factors should be kept in mind while placing intraocular lens in a child?(FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Myopic shift

 

Children have a hypermetropic eye ball. The axial length of the eye ball increases as the child grows, resulting in myopic shift. Therefore, power of the intraocular lens is under corrected to compensate for the myopic shift as follows:

 

  1. <2 years of age: 80% of IOL power (i.e. reduce IOL power by 20%)
  2. 2-8 years of age: 90% of IOL power (i.e. reduce IOL power by 10%)
  3. >8 years: 100% of IOL power (use normal calculated IOL power)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypermetropic shift: This is incorrect because the shift observed as children grow is towards myopia, not hypermetropia.

 

Option B. Increase the length of capsule: This option is incorrect as it is not a factor directly related to the placement of the IOL. The axial length of the eye increases naturally as the child grows, not the length of the capsule.

 

Option C. Increase in the size of capsule covering the diameter: This option is also incorrect. While the overall growth of the eye affects the axial length, it is the myopic shift that is the critical factor to consider when determining the power of the IOL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When placing intraocular lenses in children, it is essential to undercorrect the lens power to accommodate for the expected myopic shift as the child grows.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus which lasts minutes to hours with accompanied nausea and vomiting. On investigation, there is endolymphatic hypertension present. What is the diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Meniere’s disease

The patient's symptoms and the diagnostic finding of endolymphatic hypertension align with Meniere's disease. 

Characterized by episodes of vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness, lasting from minutes to hours. The symptoms are due to the accumulation of fluid in the inner ear (endolymphatic hydrops), leading to increased pressure within the endolymphatic system.

Other Options:

 Option B. Otosclerosis: A condition primarily affecting the bones of the middle ear, particularly the stapes. It causes conductive hearing loss, not typically associated with vertigo or tinnitus of the type seen in Meniere’s disease.

Option C. Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV): Characterized by brief episodes of vertigo related to changes in head position. It involves the dislodgment of otoliths within the inner ear, leading to brief, intense episodes of vertigo, without the auditory symptoms typical of Meniere's disease. 

Option D. Acoustic Neuroma (Vestibular Schwannoma): A benign tumor on the vestibular nerve, leading to progressive, unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and balance disturbances. It usually does not cause episodic vertigo like Meniere's disease.

Educational Objective:

Meniere’s disease is a chronic condition that requires management of symptoms through lifestyle changes, medications to control vertigo, and sometimes more invasive treatments to manage fluid pressure in the inner ear.

questions.text: Identify the part of the cochlear implant marked? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Grounding electrode

 

 

The marked part in the image is the grounding electrode, also known as the reference electrode. In a cochlear implant, the grounding electrode is usually implanted in the temporalis area. Its primary function is to serve as a reference point for electrical signals, ensuring accurate signal transmission and reducing noise interference during the processing of sound signals.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amplifier: An amplifier is not a distinct part of the cochlear implant. Instead, the sound processor amplifies and processes the sound signals before transmitting them to the receiver.

 

Option C. Receiver: The receiver in a cochlear implant is a component that lies under the skin and receives sound signals from the external transmitter. It is not the marked part in the image.

 

Option D. Electrode array: The electrode array is implanted inside the cochlea and is responsible for stimulating the auditory nerve. It directly interacts with the cochlea, unlike the grounding electrode that is positioned externally or at a different implant site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The grounding electrode or reference electrode in a cochlear implant is implanted in the temporalis area and is crucial for accurate signal transmission by providing a reference point for electrical signals.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy gets punched in the eye and the next day he developed diplopia with upward gaze. There is no congestion or proptosis of eye. What is the probable diagnosis?(FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fracture floor of orbit

 

A blow out fracture of the orbital floor is caused by sudden increase in orbital pressure due to trauma.

 

Signs:

 

  • Enophthalmos- due to inward displacement of intraorbital contents
  • Diplopia – due to extra ocular muscle (inferior rectus) entrapment in fracture
  • Infra orbital anesthesia- if fracture involves infra orbital canal through which infra orbital nerve passes.
  • Others- periorbital edema, ecchymosis, subcutaneous emphysema, etc

 

Plain X-Ray: Water’s view is the best.

 

On CT: Tear drop sign due to protrusion of orbital fat or inferior rectus muscle into maxillary sinus.

 

Most common wall to be fractured in blow-out fractures is the floor.   

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fracture roof of orbit: This would likely result in different symptoms, such as more significant pain, possible CSF leak, or symptoms indicative of frontal lobe damage. It is less likely to cause diplopia with upward gaze.

 

Option C. Intracranial hemorrhage: This would present with signs of increased intracranial pressure, altered mental status, severe headache, and other neurological deficits. Diplopia without proptosis or congestion is not typical.

 

Option D. Subdural hematoma: This condition would present with neurological symptoms such as headache, confusion, vomiting, and possibly loss of consciousness. Diplopia with upward gaze is not a characteristic symptom.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A blow-out fracture of the orbital floor is commonly associated with diplopia with upward gaze due to entrapment of the inferior rectus muscle, enophthalmos, and infraorbital anesthesia.

questions.text: An individual who is experiencing vertigo but does not have hearing impairment has consulted an ENT surgeon. The surgeon proceeds with a diagnostic technique followed by a carefully executed therapeutic procedure. What is the diagnostic maneuver?(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dix-Hallpike maneuver

 

Vertigo without hearing loss diagnosed by a positional maneuver is benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). The diagnostic maneuver used in BPPV is the Dix-Hallpike maneuver and therapeutic maneuver is the Epley's maneuver.

 

Dix-Hallpike maneuver:

 

  • Gold standard for diagnosing BPPV. 
  •  Nystagmus has a short latency period of 2-20 seconds, lasts for less than a minute, and has a fixed direction towards the lower placed ear, and is fatigable.
  • Associated with vertigo.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hampton's maneuver: This is not a widely recognized or standard maneuver in the diagnosis or treatment of vertigo. It does not relate to any commonly accepted procedure in the management of vertigo in otolaryngology.

 

Option C. Epley's maneuver: The therapeutic maneuver is the Epley maneuver which repositions the otolith to the utricle/saccule from the posterior semicircular canal.

 

 

Option D. Simon's maneuver: Like Hampton's maneuver, Simon's maneuver is not a standard or widely recognized technique in the diagnosis or management of vertigo associated with BPPV or other inner ear conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Dix-Hallpike maneuver is specifically used for diagnosing BPPV by eliciting nystagmus induced by position changes.
  • The Epley's maneuver is used to treat the vertigo symptoms once BPPV is confirmed by the Dix-Hallpike test.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 47

questions.text: 100-day glaucoma is seen in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Central retinal vein occlusion

 

  • Neovascular glaucoma (NVG) is also known as "90-" or "100-day glaucoma" due to its typical development 3 months after the onset of Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO).
  • NVG results from the occlusion of the central retinal vein, causing significant retinal ischemia and venous stasis.
  • Recurrent hemorrhages are common, and neovascularization of the retina and optic disc develop.
  • The retina undergoes pigmentary and atrophic changes.
  • NVG occurs in three stages:
    1. Pre-glaucomatous stage - stage of rubeosis iridis i.e. neovascularisation on the surface of the iris.
    2. Open-angle glaucoma stage - due to the formation of a pretrabecular neovascular membrane.
    3. Secondary angle closure glaucoma— due to goniosynechiae resulting from contracture of the neovascular membrane (zipper-angle closure).

 

 

  • Treatment of NVG is usually frustrating.
    • Pan-retinal photocoagulation may be carried out to prevent further neovascularization.
    • Medical therapy and conventional filtration surgery are usually not effective in controlling the IOP.
    • Artificial filtration shunt (valved/unvalved) may control the IOP.
  • Serious complications of central retinal vein occlusion are cystoid degeneration of the macula, optic atrophy, and hemorrhagic or neovascular glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Eale’s disease: Eales disease, also known as "primary retinal periphlebitis" or "periphlebitis retinae," is a rare inflammatory disorder that primarily affects the blood vessels in the retina of the eye. It was first described by the British ophthalmologist Henry Eales in 1880, and the condition was subsequently named after him.

 

Eales disease typically occurs in young adults, often males, and is more prevalent in certain regions, including India. The exact cause of Eales disease is not well understood, but it is believed to have an immunological basis. Some theories suggest that it may be related to immune system dysfunction, possibly triggered by an underlying infection or other factors.

 

The main features of Eales disease include:

 

  1. Retinal Vasculitis: Inflammation of the small blood vessels (veins) in the retina. This can lead to retinal hemorrhages, exudates, and swelling, which can affect vision.
  2. Neovascularization: New, abnormal blood vessels may develop as a response to the damaged retinal vessels. These abnormal vessels can be fragile and prone to bleeding, leading to further vision problems.
  3. Vitreous Hemorrhage:
  4. Retinal Detachment: In some cases, Eales disease can lead to tractional retinal detachment.

 

The symptoms of Eales disease can vary and may include blurred vision, floaters, and reduced visual acuity. Diagnosis is typically made through a thorough clinical examination, which may include the use of imaging techniques like fundus fluorescein angiography to visualize the areas of capillary non-perfusion, leakage (suggestive of neovascularisation or macular edema).

 

The treatment of Eales disease aims to control inflammation, prevent or treat complications, and preserve or improve vision. Treatment options may include systemic or local corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and macular edema, intravitreal Anti VEGF injection for macular edema, laser photocoagulation therapy to target abnormal blood vessels, and in some cases, surgical intervention (pars plana vitrectomy) to address complications like retinal detachment and vitreous haemorrhage. The specific treatment plan will depend on the severity of the disease and the individual patient's needs.

 

It's important for individuals with Eales disease to receive ongoing care and follow-up with an ophthalmologist to monitor their condition and manage any potential complications. Causative association with tuberculosis is present and patient needs to be evaluated for TB and AKT may be initiated where indicated.

 

Option C. Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) is a medical condition that occurs when the central retinal artery becomes blocked or narrowed. This blockage results in a sudden and severe loss of vision in the affected eye. CRAO is considered a medical emergency because it can lead to permanent vision loss if not treated promptly.

 

Common causes and risk factors of central retinal artery occlusion include:

 

  1. Atherosclerosis: The most common cause of CRAO is atherosclerosis.
  2. Embolism:
  3. Giant cell arteritis: This is a condition in which the arteries, including the central retinal artery, become inflamed. It primarily affects older individuals and can result in CRAO. GCA is an emergency requiring prompt initiation of systemic steroids to prevent the fellow eye from developing CRAO.
  4. Vasculitis: Occlusive inflammation of the blood vessels can lead to occlusion of the central retinal artery.

 

Symptoms of central retinal artery occlusion may include:

 

  1. Sudden, painless, and severe vision loss in one eye.
  2. The affected eye may appear pale or whitened (retinal pallor).
  3. RAPD.
  4. Cherry-red spot: Due to the contrast between the well-oxygenated macula and the poorly oxygenated surrounding retina.

 

Treatment options may include:

 

  1. Ocular massage: to dislodge the embolus causing the blockage.
  2. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy: Breathing pure oxygen in a pressurized chamber can increase oxygen delivery to the retina and may be considered in some cases.
  3. Carbogen inhalation therapy or rebreathing into a paper bag – Resultant hypercarbemia causes vasodilation which may help to dislodge the embolus and restore blood flow.
  4. Reducing intraocular pressure – by means of Anterior Chamber paracentesis or systemic acetazolamide.
  5. Surgical intervention: Optic Nerve Sheath fenestration surgery.
  6. Thrombolytic therapy: In some situations, clot-dissolving medications may be used.

 

Option D. Steroid-induced glaucoma:

 

  • Description: Glaucoma resulting from prolonged use of corticosteroids.
  • Mechanism: Steroids can increase IOP by reducing the outflow of aqueous humor.
  • Symptoms: Gradual loss of peripheral vision, halos around lights, headache, eye pain.
  • Treatment: Reducing or discontinuing steroid use, using IOP-lowering medications.

  • Note: Steroid-induced glaucoma is not associated with neovascularization or termed as 100-day glaucoma.

     

Educational Objective:

 

Neovascular glaucoma, known as "100-day glaucoma," typically develops about three months after the onset of Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO) due to significant retinal ischemia and venous stasis leading to neovascularization.

questions.text: A patient presented with a history of minor trauma 20 days back with a piece of wood. He presented as shown in the image. CT scan revealed clear sinuses and the presence of subcutaneous nodules. Microscopy of the tissue sections are positive to PAS and positive on Gomori methamine silver stain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phycomycosis

 

The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Phycomycosis /Mucormycosis.

 

It is fungal infection of nose and paranasal sinuses which may prove rapidly fatal. It is seen in uncontrolled diabetics or in those taking immunosuppressive drugs.

 

PATHOLOGY – From the nose and sinuses, infection can spread to orbit, cribriform plate, meninges and brain. The rapid destruction associated with the disease is due to affinity of the fungus to invade the arteries and cause endothelial damage and thrombosis.

 

CLINICAL FEATURES – Black necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate.

 

DIAGNOSIS – Special stains help to identify the fungus in tissue sections.

 

Black turbinate sign is seen on contrast MRI.

 

TREATMENT – Amphotericin B and surgical debridement of the affected tissues and control of underlying predisposing cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midline lethal granuloma: Primarily involves destructive lesions of the midline facial structures but lacks the fungal component.

 

Option B. Foreign body granuloma: Typically arises from a reaction to a foreign material but would not cause the extensive symptoms or be positive on the fungal stains used.

 

Option D. IgG4 granuloma: Associated with elevated levels of IgG4 and typically presents with tumefactive lesions, not primarily infectious.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phycomycosis is a serious fungal infection affecting mainly the nasal passages and sinuses, identifiable by special staining techniques and known for its aggressive, potentially fatal progression requiring prompt treatment with antifungals and surgery.

questions.text: The image of a drug is given below. It is used in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Subglottic stenosis

 

The given drug is Mitomycin-C. It is used topically in the management of subglottic stenosis.

 

Mitomycin is an antibiotic that is isolated from the broth of Streptomyces caespitosus. This drug has demonstrated antitumor activity. Mitomycin belongs to a group of alkylating agents that work by cross-linking the complementary strands found in DNA. It also has antifibrotic property which prevents tissue scarring.

 

Thus, it can used to inhibit post-surgical scar formation and as a chemotherapeutic agent.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Rhinocerebral mucormycosis - This fungal infection requires antifungal medications, not typically treated with Mitomycin-C.

 

Option C. Adenoidectomy - A surgical procedure to remove adenoids; does not involve the use of Mitomycin-C.

 

Option D. Tympanoplasty - Surgical repair of the eardrum, where Mitomycin-C is not routinely used.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Mitomycin-C is particularly effective in preventing the recurrence of subglottic stenosis after surgery due to its antifibrotic properties, making it a critical adjunct in surgical procedures involving the airway.

 

Ref - Scott Brown 8th edition, volume 3, Page No. 1088

questions.text: A 19-year-old youth was brought the casualty with a black eye following a fist fight. Which area of the orbit is most likely to have been fractured? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Floor

 

  • The most common site of an orbital blowout fracture is the floor of the orbit.
  • BLOW-out fractures involve LOW wall (means inferior wall or floor of orbit).
  • The floor consists of three bones: the zygomatic, maxillary, and palatine bones. The posteromedial portion of the maxillary bone is relatively weak and may be involved in a "blowout" fracture.
  • Clinical features:
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhage.
  • Subcutaneous emphysema affecting the eyelids (commoner with medial wall fractures)
  • Enophthalmus (inward displacement of eyeball) and mechanical ptosis
  • Infraorbital nerve anaesthesia
  • Double diplopia (diplopia in both upwards as well as downwards gaze)
  • Positive “forced duction test”
  • Management:
  • X ray (Waters view) and CT-Scan of orbit show tear drop sign.
  • Conservative management may be useful in a good number of patients.
  • However, surgical intervention if required should be done about 2 weeks of injury with synthetic material like supramide, teflon or silicon.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial wall: Less commonly involved in isolated blowout fractures; can be associated with subcutaneous emphysema.

 

Option B. Lateral wall: The strongest wall of the orbit and less likely to fracture in isolated blunt trauma.

 

Option C. Roof: More common in children due to its thinness but less common overall compared to the floor in blowout fractures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The floor of the orbit is the most likely site of fracture in cases of orbital blowout fractures resulting from blunt trauma, such as a fist fight. Key clinical features include enophthalmos, infraorbital nerve anesthesia, and diplopia. Imaging with X-rays and CT scans are crucial for diagnosis and surgical intervention may be required for severe cases.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with drooping of eyelids in both eyes which worsens as the day passes. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myasthenia gravis

 

Weakness of eyelid muscles that exacerbates at the end of the day is characteristic of myasthenia gravis.

 

Myasthenia Gravis

 

Myasthenia patients have lower motor neuron type palsy, despite the muscle weakness, deep tendon reflexes are preserved. Hence DTRs are present. Muscle bulk is also normal and there are no fasciculations as there is involvement of neuromuscular junction rather than LMN.

 

Diagnosis

 

History

 

  • Diplopia, ptosis, dysarthria, dysphagia, dyspnea.
  • Weakness in characteristic distribution: Proximal limbs, neck extensors, generalized.
  • Fluctuation and fatigue: Worse with repeated activity, improved by rest.

 

Physical Examination

 

  • Ptosis, diplopia
  • Motor power survey: Quantitative testing of muscle strength
  • Forward arm abduction time (5 mm)
  • Vital capacity measurement
  • Absence of other neurologic signs
  • If weakness of respiration becomes as severe as to require respiratory assistance, the patient is said to be in crisis.

 

Laboratory Testing

 

  • Anti-AChR radioimmunoassay: 85% positive in generalized MG; 50% in ocular MG; definite diagnosis if positive; negative result does not exclude MG; 40% of AChR antibody—negative patients with generalized MG have anti-MuSK antibodies.
  • Repetitive nerve stimulation: Decrement of >15% at 3 Hz: highly probable.
  • Single-fiber electromyography: Blocking and jitter, with normal fiber density; confirmatory, but not specific.
  • Edrophonium chloride 2 mg + 8 mg IV; highly probable diagnosis if unequivocally positive.
  • For ocular or cranial MG: Exclude intracranial lesions by CT or MRI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Horner syndrome: Characterized by ptosis, miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on the affected side. The ptosis in Horner syndrome is usually mild and not worsened by activity.

 

Option C. Blepharitis: Involves inflammation of the eyelids, leading to redness, irritation, and crusting. It does not typically cause fluctuating ptosis.

 

Option D. Progressive ophthalmoplegia: Refers to gradual paralysis of the extraocular muscles. While it can cause ptosis, the pattern of muscle weakness in progressive ophthalmoplegia does not usually fluctuate with activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia gravis is characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest, commonly presenting with ptosis and diplopia.

questions.text: The patient exhibited surgical emphysema following an urgent tracheostomy. What is the probable cause behind this occurrence? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Tear in posterior tracheal wall

 

Subcutaneous emphysema is a relatively uncommon complication that can arise from a tracheostomy procedure. However, it poses a significant threat to the patient's well-being, as it can lead to severe morbidity and even mortality, particularly if it advances to pneumothorax and pneumomediastinum. This condition occurs when the tissues surrounding the tracheostomy tube are tightly sealed or when there are tears in the posterior tracheal wall.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High Tracheostomy: While a high tracheostomy can cause other complications (like damage to the laryngeal nerves or cricoid cartilage), it is less likely to cause surgical emphysema unless associated with a tear or improper technique.

 

Option C. Block in Tracheostomy Tube: A blocked tracheostomy tube typically leads to respiratory distress from inadequate ventilation, rather than surgical emphysema.

 

Option D. Pulmonary Oedema: Pulmonary oedema involves fluid accumulation in the lungs and does not cause surgical emphysema. It presents with different symptoms such as difficulty breathing, coughing up pink frothy sputum, and increased work of breathing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surgical emphysema following tracheostomy is a serious complication, often due to a tear in the posterior tracheal wall. This condition requires immediate attention to manage the airway, assess the extent of air spread, and prevent further complications. Effective management includes careful monitoring, possibly surgical repair of the tear, and measures to control the air leakage and its sequelae.
